name: behave-vsc

behave-vsc.envVarList.description:
Optional SINGLE-quoted csv list of environment variables to use when calling a behave command
Example: 'var1': 'val1', 'var2': 'val2'
(You can escape any contained single quotes like this: 'var3':'myva\'lue', or \\' in the settings.json file itself.)

behave-vsc.fastSkipList.description:
Optional csv list of fast skip tags that each start with @
Example: @skip, @skipped
This setting has no effect when you run all tests at once and runAllAsOne is enabled, or when debugging.
The listed tags will stop behave being called for features/scenarios marked with those tags. Use if you have a lot of tests to skip.
Useful only if you have a large amount of skipped tests and either (a) you have grouped your tests into folders, or (b) you are not using runAllAsOne.

behave-vsc.featuresPath.description:
Optional setting for workspace-relative features subfolder.
Example: mysubfolder/my_behave_tests
If empty, it will be set to features.
If not set to empty string or features, then this must match the "path=" setting in your behave configuration file.

behave-vsc.justMyCode.description:
Default true (enabled).
Controls whether to step into external code when debugging a behave test.

behave-vsc.runAllAsOne.description:
Default:true (enabled).
When running all tests, use a single 'python -m behave'.
Recommended to keep this enabled unless either/both (a) you can enable runParallel or (b) you are using fastSkipList with a lot of tests.
Note that running running a sub-selection of tests vs one-shot run all may give different results, i.e. highlight issues with test isolation.

behave-vsc.runParallel.description:
Default:false (disabled).
Run tests in async mode.
This setting has no effect when you are running all tests at once and runAllAsOne is enabled.
Leave this off for your initial run, then enable if you wish and your test setup supports it (i.e. your tests are fully isolated).
Note that behave itself does not support parallel testing - enabling this setting will create multiple behave instances, so in the case of running all tests, it may or may not be faster due to the overhead of starting multiple processes. It depends on a lot of factors, for example, slow tests are likely to run faster because they can execute at the same time, but fast tests might be slower due to the overhead.
